qas.question: Where did Dominic and his followers live during early 1220?

answers.text: the ancient Roman basilica of Santa Sabina

qas.question: Who invited Dominic to stay in the Roman Basilica of Santa Sabina?
What was required of each new priory?
When did Pope Honorius III transfer property to the Order of Preachers?
The College of Saint Thomas became what institution of learning in the 20th Century?

answers.text: the Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, Angelicum

plausible_answers.text: the ancient Roman basilica of Santa Sabina

qas.question: Where did Dominic and his followers live in during early 1320?
What pope did not invite Dominic to stay in the Roman basilica of Santa Sabina?
When did Pope John Paul II transfer property to the Order of Preachers?

context: In 1219 <a1_0>Pope <b6_0>Honorius III<b6_0/><a1_0/> invited Saint Dominic and his companions to take up residence at <a0_0><b5_0>the ancient Roman basilica of Santa Sabina<b5_0/><a0_0/>, which they did by early 1220. Before that time the friars had only a temporary residence in Rome at the convent of San Sisto Vecchio which Honorius III had given to Dominic circa 1218 intending it to become a convent for a reformation of nuns at Rome under Dominic's guidance. In May 1220 at Bologna the order's first General Chapter mandated that each new priory of the order maintain <a2_0>its own studium conventuale<a2_0/> thus laying the foundation of the Dominican tradition of sponsoring widespread institutions of learning. The official foundation of the Dominican convent at Santa Sabina with its studium conventuale occurred with the legal transfer of property from Honorius III to the Order of Preachers on <a3_0><b7_0>June 5, 1222<b7_0/><a3_0/>. This studium was transformed into the order's first studium provinciale by Saint Thomas Aquinas in 1265. Part of the curriculum of this studium was relocated in 1288 at the studium of Santa Maria sopra Minerva which in the 16th century world be transformed into the College of Saint Thomas (Latin: Collegium Divi Thomæ). In the 20th century the college would be relocated to the convent of Saints Dominic and Sixtus and would be transformed into <a4_0>the Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, Angelicum<a4_0/>.
